Why I Started Krypto Hashers Community (KHC)

â¤ï¸ Krishna Chaitanya December 30, 2023

This journey started way before the community even existed â€” back when I was just another solo dev, picking up random projects and diving headfirst into stuff without really knowing what I was doing.

For the past few years, Iâ€™ve been in that phase where I was building just for the sake of building. I never waited to become an â€œexpertâ€ in anything â€” I was the type to see something that looked cool and just go for it. Sometimes it worked out, but more often than not, I found myself in over my head. Iâ€™d get stuck on some crazy bug or some issue that I had absolutely no idea how to solve. And without a mentor, or even a senior dev to ask for help, I was left on my own â€” trying to troubleshoot at 11 PM, googling random solutions and hoping something would work.

Some nights, Iâ€™d stay up for hours, struggling with code, desperately trying to figure out how to move forward. At some point, I realized that I couldnâ€™t be the only one going through this. So, I started reaching out to people â€” other devs, more experienced than me, from different fields of coding. Some of them ignored me. Some ghosted me entirely. But a lot of them actually took the time to reply. They helped me, shared their knowledge, and even collaborated on projects with me. Slowly but surely, I started learning more and improving my skills. I realized that the real power came from community â€” from sharing ideas and solving problems together.

And then it hit me â€” why not create a space for others like me? A place where people who are stuck, people who are just starting out or learning by doing, can come together and help each other. Not a fancy startup or a perfectly polished community, but a real, raw place where devs could connect, collaborate, and grow together. And thatâ€™s how Krypto Hashers Community (KHC) was born.

At first, the community was all about crypto projects. Thatâ€™s where I was putting most of my energy, so it made sense to keep it focused on that. But over time, KHC grew into something deeper â€” something more personal. I realized that KHC didnâ€™t just have to be about crypto. It could be a place for anyone who was building, learning, or struggling â€” anyone who needed help and wanted to grow. So, I decided to keep the name, even though it had a deep personal meaning for me. I didnâ€™t want to change it. KHC had become more than just a space for crypto devs. It had become a community for anyone trying to build, learn, and not get stuck alone.

Looking back, itâ€™s crazy how much has changed since I first started.
